title: Jānis Fabriciuss
text:
Jānis Fabriciuss (<a href="Russian%20language">Russian</a>: Ян Фри́цевич Фабри́циус, "Jan Fritsevich Fabricius"; June 14  [26], 1877, near the <a href="Zl%C4%93kas%20Parish">Zlekas Parish</a>, now the <a href="Ventspils">Ventspils</a> region of Latvia – August 24, 1929 near <a href="Sochi">Sochi</a>) was a Latvian <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet</a> commander and <a href="Political%20Commissar">commissar</a> of the <a href="Red%20Army">Red Army</a>.
Biography.
Jānis Fabriciuss was born into the family of Latvian farm workers near Ventspils in the <a href="Courland%20Governorate">Courland Governorate</a>. He was active in the revolutionary movement since 1891 and participated in different protests such as the "Potato Riots" which was a workers' strike in Windawa. He graduated from the <a href="Alexander%20Gymnasium">Alexander Gymnasium</a> in Riga in 1894.
He started his military in the <a href="Imperial%20Russian%20Army">Imperial Russian Army</a> in 1900 and served in the <a href="Lithuanian%20Life%20Guard%20Regiment">Lithuanian Life Guard Regiment</a>. After being transferred reserve, he worked at a Riga machine-building plant. Fabriciuss joined of the <a href="Russian%20Social%20Democratic%20Labour%20Party">Russian Social Democratic Labour Party</a> in 1903 and in 1904, he was sentenced by the Riga District Court to four years in hard labor with subsequent exile to Yakutia. During the years 1913 to 1915, he served his exile in <a href="Sakhalin">Sakhalin</a>.
In 1915 he was again called up for military service and enlisted in the 1st <a href="Latvian%20Riflemen">Latvian Rifle Regiment</a>. He fought with the regiment on the Northern Front and was wounded four times. He rose to the rank of senior non-commissioned officer. According to other publications of the post-Soviet period, by the <a href="February%20Revolution">February Revolution</a>, Fabricius was still on Sakhalin.
On April 23, 1917, he was member of the Sakhalin Council of Workers' and Soldiers' Deputies, after which he leaves for Moscow.
From January 1918 he was member of the <a href="All-Russian%20Central%20Executive%20Committee">All-Russian Central Executive Committee</a>. From February 1918 he served as the commander of the <a href="Gdovsky%20Uyezd">Gdov</a> detachment and then military commissar of the Gdov-Toroshinsky region, the chairman of the <a href="Military%20Revolutionary%20Committee">Military Revolutionary Committee</a> of the <a href="Pskov%20Oblast">Pskov</a> district. Fabriciuss distinguished himself in battles against the German interventionists and rebel formations under the command of <a href="Stanis%C5%82aw%20Bu%C5%82ak-Ba%C5%82achowicz">Sergei Bulak-Balakhovich</a>. In late 1918 - early 1919, he was the commissar of the 2nd Novgorod rifle division during the liberation of Latvia.
On February 13, 1919, Fabriciuss was awarded the <a href="Order%20of%20the%20Red%20Banner">Order of the Red Banner</a> No. 4, becoming one of the first holders of the highest award (at that time) of the <a href="Russian%20Soviet%20Federative%20Socialist%20Republic">RSFSR</a>.
From February 1919, he was a military commissar of the <a href="10th%20Rifle%20Division%20%28Soviet%20Union%29">10th Rifle Division</a> in battles in Estonia. From August 1919, the head of the Livno-Yeletsk defense region for the campaign against the cavalry of <a href="Konstantin%20Mamontov">Konstantin Mamontov</a> during his of the southern of the Soviet troops. From October 1919, he was the commander of the 48th Infantry Brigade of the 16th Infantry Division of the <a href="8th%20Army%20%28RSFSR%29">8th Army</a> of the Red Army and took part in the defeat of the troops of General <a href="Anton%20Denikin">A.I. Denikin</a> and in the Soviet-Polish war. From January 1921 he was the chief and military commissar of the 43rd United Courses of the command staff of the Red Army. He was a delegate of the <a href="10th%20Congress%20of%20the%20Russian%20Communist%20Party%20%28Bolsheviks%29">10th Congress of the Communist Party</a>. He participated in the suppression of the <a href="Kronstadt%20rebellion">Kronstadt Mutiny</a> of 1921 as the commander of the 501st Infantry Regiment.
Fabriciuss served as the first commander of the <a href="United%20Belarusian%20Military%20School">United Belarusian Military School</a> from 1921 to 1922.
From January 1924  he was the commander of the 17th Rifle Corps in the <a href="Kiev%20Military%20District">Ukrainian Military District</a>.
Commander of the <a href="4th%20Rifle%20Corps%23First%20formation">4th Rifle Corps</a> in Vitebsk (1927-1928) and in 1928, assistant commander of the <a href="Red%20Banner%20Caucasus%20Army">Red Banner Caucasus Army</a> (KKA). From 1927 he was a member of the <a href="Central%20Control%20Commission%20of%20the%20Communist%20Party%20of%20the%20Soviet%20Union">Central Control Commission</a> of the VKP (b).
On August 24, 1929, Fabriciuss drowned while rescuing the drowning passengers of the <a href="Kalinin%20K-4">Kalinin K-4</a> plane, which suffered a plane crash and fell into the sea near the city of Sochi.
Awards.
Fabriciuss is the first four-time holder of the highest state award (at that time), the <a href="Order%20of%20the%20Red%20Banner">Order of the Red Banner</a>. The first order was awarded in 1919 "For continuous selfless work at the front in fire", the second, "For distinction in breaking through the defense of the White Poles near Smorgon on July 14, 1920", the third, "for participation in the suppression of the Kronstadt rebellion", the fourth, "for battles in the attack on Warsaw and subsequent rearguard battles "in 1921. According to the official version, the Order of the Red Banner No. 4 was awarded to Fabricius in 1919. According to another version, this order was attributed to him later, already retroactively.
He was also a recipient of the <a href="Honorary%20Revolutionary%20Weapon">Honorary Revolutionary Weapon</a>.
